raw_text:
WorldCom trial starts in New York
 
 The trial of Bernie Ebbers, former chief executive of bankrupt US phone company WorldCom, has started in New York with the selection of the jury.
 
 Mr Ebbers, 63, is accused of being the mastermind behind an $11bn (£6bn) accounting fraud that eventually saw the firm collapse in July 2002. His indictment includes charges of securities fraud, conspiracy and filing false reports with regulators. If found guilty, Mr Ebbers could face a substantial jail sentence. He has firmly declared his innocence.
 
 Under Mr Ebbers' leadership, WorldCom emerged from Mississippi obscurity to become a $160bn telecoms giant and the darling of late 1990s investors. Yet as competition intensified and the telecoms boom petered out, WorldCom found itself under growing financial stress. When WorldCom finally collapsed, shareholders lost about $180bn and 20,000 workers lost their jobs. Mr Ebbers' trial, which is expected to last two months, is the latest in a series of attempts by US prosecutors to pursue senior executives for fraud. It will coincide with the retrial of former Tyco International chief Dennis Kozlowski and his top lieutenant, accused of looting the industrial conglomerate to the tune of $600m. Trail preparations are also preparing for former executives of shamed US energy firm Enron.
llama3.2:1b:
The WorldCom trial started in New York with the selection of a jury.

Bernie Ebbers is being tried on charges of securities fraud, conspiracy, and filing false reports with regulators.
He faces up to 20 years in prison if found guilty.
Ebbers denies being involved in the $11bn accounting fraud that led to WorldCom's collapse.
llama3.2:3b: The trial of Bernie Ebbers, former WorldCom CEO, has started in New York with charges including securities fraud, conspiracy and filing false reports. Ebbers, 63, denies the allegations and could face a substantial jail sentence if found guilty. The trial is part of a series of attempts by US prosecutors to pursue senior executives for fraud.
gemma2:2b: Bernie Ebbers' trial for accounting fraud at WorldCom has begun in New York. He faces charges of securities fraud and conspiracy stemming from an alleged $11 billion fraud that led to the company's collapse in 2002. If convicted, he could face jail time.  This trial is part of a broader effort by US prosecutors to hold executives accountable for fraud, including the upcoming retrial of Dennis Kozlowski and other former executives of Enron.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The WorldCom trial in New York is starting with a jury selection. The main suspects are Bernie Ebbers, who is accused of fraud and securities manipulation at WorldCom. If convicted, he could face significant jail time. His company was once the darling of late 1990s investors but eventually declined due to financial strain and competition. Former executives like Dennis Kozlowski and former Enron executives are also under investigation.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The trial of Bernie Ebbers, former CEO of bankrupt WorldCom, has begun in New York with a jury selection. Ebbers faces charges including securities fraud and conspiracy related to an $11 billion accounting scandal. If convicted, he could face substantial jail time. WorldCom collapsed due to financial stress from intensified competition and declining telecoms boom, leading to shareholder losses and 20,000 job cuts.
qwen2.5:3b: WorldCom's former CEO Bernie Ebbers begins trial in New York with jury selection; charged with orchestrating $11bn accounting fraud leading to company collapse in 2002. If convicted, could face lengthy jail time despite his declared innocence. His leadership transformed WorldCom from a Mississippi-based firm into a $160bn telecom giant before its bankruptcy and subsequent economic fallout affected thousands of workers. Ebbers' trial will follow similar efforts by US prosecutors to hold executives accountable for fraud, including the retrial of Tyco International's Dennis Kozlowski and Enron's former executives.
opencoder:1.5b: The trial of Mr. Bernie Ebbers, a former chairman of WorldCom's bankrupt phone company, has started in New York with the selection of the jury. Mr. Ebbers is accused of an accounting fraud that resulted in the firm collapsing in July 2002. Under his leadership, WorldCom emerged as a telecom giant and became a market leader in late 1980s. Yet as competition grew and the boom petered out, financial stress also increased, leading to loss of shareholders and workers.

tinyllama:1.1b: United States judge has selected the jury in the trial of Bernie Ebber, former CEO of bankrupt US telecommunication company WorldCom. The trial is set to start next week and will involve charges of accounting fraud, securities violations, and filing false reports with regulators. If found guilty, Mr Ebber could face a significant sentence. Under his leadership, WorldCom became a $160bn telecoms giant and the darling of late 90s investors. However, as competition intensified and the telecommunications boom petered out, WorldCom found itself under financial stress. The trial, which is expected to last two months, coincides with the retrieval of former Tyco International CEO Dennis Kozylowski and his top lieutenant, accused of looting the company to the tune of $600m. Other key individuals on trial are former executives of energy firm Enron.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The world's biggest telecom company, WorldCom, is set to go to court in New York. 

Bernie Ebbers, its ex-chief executive, will stand in the dock facing allegations of accounting fraud and conspiracy. 

He denies the charges but has said that he was not involved in the wrongdoing. The trial is expected to take place for two months.

The trial is part of a series of attempts by US prosecutors to pursue senior executives for fraud, along with other high-profile cases such as Tyco International's retrial and former Enron executives' trials.
